messages: 28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:37): how come there's a huge difference in rendering (nowadays?) between gecko and webkit?
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:37): I suddenly have a lot of inconsitencies...
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:38): There usually isn't
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:38): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: I know but i got a certain design atm
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:38): where it looks perfect in Webkit and totally fubar'd in firefox
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:38): and really... confused
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (21:43): create a minimal testcase and post it here :-)
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:43): sure wait a sec lemme upload

cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:47): note that firefox 3.x doesnt use the html5 parser. some valid constructs are completely b0rked. e.g. <a ...><div>...</div></a> will *randomly* break. it's a timing issue which depends on reflows. as such, things like gzip, length, latency, and the phase of the moon affect it :I
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:47): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: http://bastardoperatorfromhell.org/~jakoury/contact.html
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:48): oh and I get one interesting error which I understand but... thought I was allowed
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:49): not allowed to use a <header> inside a <header> but I thought it's allowed if you start a new <section> or <article>
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:49): 28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8, section and so forth need a display:block
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:49): try eric's new reset
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:49): it's a good starting point
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:49): http://meyerweb.com/eric/tools/css/reset/
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:50): (unknown elements default to display:inline)
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:50): cool talking a look
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:51): cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb: small change but getting closer
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:51): 28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8: what's the use case for header in section or article in header?
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:52): well I'm afraid indeed that I gotta rewrite that part... hehe... I started on index.html and worked from there but THERE the header made sense
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:52): here it should just be a normal div I think
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:52): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, s/header in section/section in header/?
cc7bcfbc58c467939c5987584fc882cb (21:52): 28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8, add overflow:hidden to #top
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:53): header in (section or article) in header
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (21:54): That's not the canonical operator precedence :)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (21:55): 28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8: i'm asking because maybe the spec should be changed if there is a use case. what did you have when it made sense?

28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:56): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: well, on the index page I had a <header> because it was the top part of the page (the head) and underneat it had the rest. but INSIDE that header I needed later to add some other thingies and that also needed a header inside...
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:57): thing I'm missing the most for an <article> is something in between <header> and <footer> (like a <body>)
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:57): cause explaining that <article> had a column-count of 2 makes everything go all whooey, but now I wrap the <p>'s inbetween <header> and <footer> in a <div>
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (21:58): 28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8: looks like we don't support position:relative with 'right' and 'bottom'
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (21:59): Isn't that kind of basic?
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:59): I refereshed and poof
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (21:59): it looks the same
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (21:59): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: I don't think anyone ever uses anything but 'left' and 'top' for relative positioning
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (21:59): I didn't even know you *could* use right and bottom
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:00): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: well cause this crazy designer thought of aligning it to the right
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:00): and then it's easier to measure it from there
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:00): I guess for relative positioning, right and bottom are equivalent to the negative of left and top?
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:00): checkout the prijzen.html
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:00): For absolute positioning, obviously there's a really big difference, so you'd use all of them.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:00): we would have noticed by now if right and bottom didn't work for abs-pos :-)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (22:01): nothing's better than the things that are broken and seem like they can't possibly actually be broken
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:01): ok now off to fiddle with getting custom radiobuttons
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:02): this designer wants to have a 3px solid #a40061 border around a circle
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:02): instead of the normal thingies
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:02): wow, I think we don't even have a bug on file about this
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:03): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: refresh this: http://bastardoperatorfromhell.org/~jakoury/contact.html position problem has been solved
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:03): but only thing I changed... was the overflow: none
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:03): we do have code for this
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:03): so something else is broken
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:03): need minimal testcase, etc
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:03): at least file a bug
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:10): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: uhm... I'd love to but... not sure what just fixed it actually
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:13): oh, that was my psychic powers
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (22:14): many developers find that their presence makes users unable to reproduce bugs
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:30): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: it's the common law of computing
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:30): users call for their sysadmin (me) and suddenly the problem they had is gone
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:31): big chance that when I check tomorrow the bug is back ;) haha

28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:41): question maybe someone here can clarify: I understand that during development of new features there's a -webkit or -moz prefix to a css property but for example the border-radius and -moz-border-radius has (afaik) the same syntax. Why not then have it as just border-radius?
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (22:44): There are still bugs with -moz-border-radius
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (22:45): This way, you know -moz-border-radius will have the bugs, while border-radius in a future version of firefox will not
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (22:45): (at least not major bugs that they know about)
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:45): hmm makes sense
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:51): Also, they don't have the same syntax for the longhand, iirc
28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8 (22:53): this site is gonna be an all nighter I'm afraid
353fa4cc248867e98de9cab7d122c320 (23:05): -moz-border-radius is not the best example
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (23:09): 28950ba3217cfb27f374b6b58585a6f8: you can't know that border-radius is going to have the same syntax until the spec is finished
